title.narrative:
1) Protection of Human Rights in UN and non-UN peace operations continue to be part of the mandate and pre-requisite for international support, and the ability to effectively protect human rights in peace operations is improved. Recognition by the Security Council, Member States, and troop & police contributing countries that the Human Rights “Compliance Framework” approach is a key element of UN and UN-authorised peace operations.
2) The framework for human rights in UN and UN authorised peace operations are strengthened.

1) Security Council resolutions call for the establishment of a Human Rights Compliance Framework in the authorisation, establishment and/or reconfiguration of peace operations (both UN and non-UN). Security Council resolutions/press statements recognise the positive impact of the “Compliance Framework” approach. Member States make public statements supporting the “Compliance Framework” approach.
2) The UN and UN Human Rights has improved capacity and tools for planning/deploying/transitioning UN peace operations.

title.narrative: 1) Human rights operational models for peace operations are adapted to new complex conflict environment 2) A policy framework is adopted on human rights readiness parameters for troop/police contributing countries (T/PCCs)

1) A study is conducted that collects and analyses detailed inputs from current human rights components in peace operations. The study includes a general overview of deployed human rights components, identifying the differences between them and the reasons behind these differences and the impact that these structural configurations have towards operations. The study will suggest best practices, note gaps and challenges, and recommend a blueprint for future HR configurations in asymmetric threat environments. Development of good practices and models based on existing military compliance mechanisms in select UN TCC and regional organisations such as NATO. 2) A study is conducted that collects and analyses information on existing human rights readiness mechanisms employed in force generation by UN/AU T/PCCS. The study will suggest best practices, note gaps and challenges, and recommend a blueprint for a Human Rights readiness policy for the UN and its contributors.
